trans-unit.source: Handle conflicts with offline data in universal Windows apps | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Handle conflicts with offline data in universal Windows apps | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services handle conflicts when syncing offline data in your universal Windows application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services handle conflicts when syncing offline data in your universal Windows application

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to synchronize data and handle conflicts when using the offline capabilities of Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to synchronize data and handle conflicts when using the offline capabilities of Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: If you prefer to watch a video, the clip below follows the same steps as this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you prefer to watch a video, the clip below follows the same steps as this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you download a universal Windows C# solution for an app that supports handling offline synchronization conflicts.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you download a universal Windows C# solution for an app that supports handling offline synchronization conflicts.

trans-unit.source: You will integrate a mobile service with the app, and then run the Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 clients to generate a sync conflict and resolve it.
trans-unit.target: You will integrate a mobile service with the app, and then run the Windows Store 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 clients to generate a sync conflict and resolve it.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial builds on the steps and the sample app from the previous tutorial [Get started with offline data].
trans-unit.target: This tutorial builds on the steps and the sample app from the previous tutorial [Get started with offline data].

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you should first complete [Get started with offline data].
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you should first complete [Get started with offline data].

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2013 running on Windows 8.1.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires Visual Studio 2013 running on Windows 8.1.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is a walkthrough of how the [Todo Offline Mobile Services sample] handles sync conflicts between the local offline store and the Mobile Service database in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is a walkthrough of how the [Todo Offline Mobile Services sample] handles sync conflicts between the local offline store and the Mobile Service database in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Download the zip file for the [Mobile Services Samples GitHub Repository] and extract it to a working directory.
trans-unit.target: Download the zip file for the [Mobile Services Samples GitHub Repository] and extract it to a working directory.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already installed SQLite for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 as mentioned in the [Get started with offline data] tutorial, install both runtimes.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already installed SQLite for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 as mentioned in the [Get started with offline data] tutorial, install both runtimes.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio 2013, open the mobile-services-samples\TodoOffline\WindowsUniversal\TodoOffline-Universal.sln solution file.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio 2013, open the mobile-services-samples\TodoOffline\WindowsUniversal\TodoOffline-Universal.sln solution file.

trans-unit.source: Press the F5 key to rebuild and run the project.
trans-unit.target: Press the F5 key to rebuild and run the project.

trans-unit.source: Verify the NuGet packages are restored and the references are correctly set.
trans-unit.target: Verify the NuGet packages are restored and the references are correctly set.

trans-unit.source: You may need to delete any old references to the SQLite runtime and replace them with the updated reference as mentioned in the [Get started with offline data] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You may need to delete any old references to the SQLite runtime and replace them with the updated reference as mentioned in the [Get started with offline data] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type some text in Insert a TodoItem, then click Save to add some todo items to the local store.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type some text in Insert a TodoItem, then click Save to add some todo items to the local store.

trans-unit.source: Then close the app.
trans-unit.target: Then close the app.

trans-unit.source: Note that the app is not yet connected to any mobile service, so the buttons Push and Pull will throw exceptions.
trans-unit.target: Note that the app is not yet connected to any mobile service, so the buttons Push and Pull will throw exceptions.

trans-unit.source: Now it's time to test the app against Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: Now it's time to test the app against Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure Management Portal, find your mobile service's application key by clicking Manage Keys on the command bar of the Dashboard tab.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure Management Portal, find your mobile service's application key by clicking Manage Keys on the command bar of the Dashboard tab.

trans-unit.source: Copy the Application Key.
trans-unit.target: Copy the Application Key.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the App.xaml.cs file in the client sample project.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, open the App.xaml.cs file in the client sample project.

trans-unit.source: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient to use your mobile service URL and application key:
trans-unit.target: Change the initialization of the MobileServiceClient to use your mobile service URL and application key:

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to build and run the app again.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, press the F5 key to build and run the app again.

trans-unit.source: In a real world scenario, a sync conflict would occur when one app pushes updates to a record in the database, and then another app tries to push an update to the same record using an outdated version field in that record.
trans-unit.target: In a real world scenario, a sync conflict would occur when one app pushes updates to a record in the database, and then another app tries to push an update to the same record using an outdated version field in that record.

trans-unit.source: If you recall from the [Get started with offline data], the version system property is required to support the offline syncing features.
trans-unit.target: If you recall from the [Get started with offline data], the version system property is required to support the offline syncing features.

trans-unit.source: This version information is examined with each database update.
trans-unit.target: This version information is examined with each database update.

trans-unit.source: If an instance of the app tries to update a record using an outdated version, a conflict will occur and be caught as a MobileServicePreconditionFailedException in the app.
trans-unit.target: If an instance of the app tries to update a record using an outdated version, a conflict will occur and be caught as a MobileServicePreconditionFailedException in the app.

trans-unit.source: If the app doesn't catch the MobileServicePreconditionFailedException then a MobileServicePushFailedException will end up being thrown describing how many sync errors were encountered.
trans-unit.target: If the app doesn't catch the MobileServicePreconditionFailedException then a MobileServicePushFailedException will end up being thrown describing how many sync errors were encountered.

trans-unit.source: To support synchronization of deleted records with offline data sync, you should enable <linkText>Soft Delete</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To support synchronization of deleted records with offline data sync, you should enable <linkText>Soft Delete</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, you have to manually remove records in the local store, or call IMobileServiceSyncTable::PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, you have to manually remove records in the local store, or call IMobileServiceSyncTable::PurgeAsync() to purge the local store.

trans-unit.source: The following steps show the Windows Phone 8.1 and Windows Store 8.1 clients running at the same time to cause and resolve a conflict using the sample.
trans-unit.target: The following steps show the Windows Phone 8.1 and Windows Store 8.1 clients running at the same time to cause and resolve a conflict using the sample.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right click the Windows Phone 8.1 project and click Set as Startup Project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right click the Windows Phone 8.1 project and click Set as Startup Project.

trans-unit.source: Then press Ctrl+F5 keys to run the Windows Phone 8.1 client without debugging.
trans-unit.target: Then press Ctrl+F5 keys to run the Windows Phone 8.1 client without debugging.

trans-unit.source: Once you have the Windows Phone 8.1 client up and running in the emulator, click the Pull button to sync the local store with the current state of the database.
trans-unit.target: Once you have the Windows Phone 8.1 client up and running in the emulator, click the Pull button to sync the local store with the current state of the database.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right click the Windows 8.1 runtime project and click Set as Startup Project to set it back to the start up project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right click the Windows 8.1 runtime project and click Set as Startup Project to set it back to the start up project.

trans-unit.source: Then press F5 to run it.
trans-unit.target: Then press F5 to run it.

trans-unit.source: Once you have the Windows Store 8.1 client up and running, click the Pull button to sync the local store with the current state of the database.
trans-unit.target: Once you have the Windows Store 8.1 client up and running, click the Pull button to sync the local store with the current state of the database.

trans-unit.source: At this point point both clients are synchronized with the database.
trans-unit.target: At this point point both clients are synchronized with the database.

trans-unit.source: The code for both clients are also using incremental sync, so that they will only sync incomplete todo items.
trans-unit.target: The code for both clients are also using incremental sync, so that they will only sync incomplete todo items.

trans-unit.source: Completed todo items will be ignored.
trans-unit.target: Completed todo items will be ignored.

trans-unit.source: Choose one of the items and edit the text of the same item in both clients to a different value.
trans-unit.target: Choose one of the items and edit the text of the same item in both clients to a different value.

trans-unit.source: Click the Push button to sync both changes with the database on the server.
trans-unit.target: Click the Push button to sync both changes with the database on the server.

trans-unit.source: The client whose push was executing last encounters the conflict and allows the user to decide which value to commit to the database.
trans-unit.target: The client whose push was executing last encounters the conflict and allows the user to decide which value to commit to the database.

trans-unit.source: The exception provides the correct version value which is used for resolving the conflict.
trans-unit.target: The exception provides the correct version value which is used for resolving the conflict.

trans-unit.source: In order to use the offline features for Mobile Services, you must include the version column in both your local database and your data transfer object.
trans-unit.target: In order to use the offline features for Mobile Services, you must include the version column in both your local database and your data transfer object.

trans-unit.source: This is accomplished by updating the TodoItem class the following member:
trans-unit.target: This is accomplished by updating the TodoItem class the following member:

trans-unit.source: The __version column is included in the local database in the OnNavigatedTo() method when the TodoItem class is used to define the local store.
trans-unit.target: The __version column is included in the local database in the OnNavigatedTo() method when the TodoItem class is used to define the local store.

trans-unit.source: To handle offline sync conflicts in your code, you create a class that implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.
trans-unit.target: To handle offline sync conflicts in your code, you create a class that implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.

trans-unit.source: Pass an object of this type in the call to MobileServiceClient.SyncContext.InitializeAsync().
trans-unit.target: Pass an object of this type in the call to MobileServiceClient.SyncContext.InitializeAsync().

trans-unit.source: This also occurs in the OnNavigatedTo() method of the sample.
trans-unit.target: This also occurs in the OnNavigatedTo() method of the sample.

trans-unit.source: The class SyncHandler in SyncHandler.cs implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.
trans-unit.target: The class SyncHandler in SyncHandler.cs implements IMobileServiceSyncHandler.

trans-unit.source: The method ExecuteTableOperationAsync is called when each push operation is sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: The method ExecuteTableOperationAsync is called when each push operation is sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: If an exception of type MobileServicePreconditionFailedException is thrown, this means that there is a conflict between the local and remote versions of an item.
trans-unit.target: If an exception of type MobileServicePreconditionFailedException is thrown, this means that there is a conflict between the local and remote versions of an item.

trans-unit.source: To resolve conflicts in favor of the local item, you should simply retry the operation.
trans-unit.target: To resolve conflicts in favor of the local item, you should simply retry the operation.

trans-unit.source: Once a conflict has occurred, the local item version will be updated to match the server version, so executing the operation again will overwrite the server changes with the local changes:
trans-unit.target: Once a conflict has occurred, the local item version will be updated to match the server version, so executing the operation again will overwrite the server changes with the local changes:

trans-unit.source: To resolve conflicts in favor of the server item, simply return from the ExecuteTableOperationAsync.
trans-unit.target: To resolve conflicts in favor of the server item, simply return from the ExecuteTableOperationAsync.

trans-unit.source: The local version of the object will be discarded and replaced with the value from the server.
trans-unit.target: The local version of the object will be discarded and replaced with the value from the server.

trans-unit.source: To stop the push operation (but retain the queued changes), use the method AbortPush():
trans-unit.target: To stop the push operation (but retain the queued changes), use the method AbortPush():

trans-unit.source: This will stop the current push operation but will keep all pending changes, including the current operation if AbortPush is called from ExecuteTableOperationAsync.
trans-unit.target: This will stop the current push operation but will keep all pending changes, including the current operation if AbortPush is called from ExecuteTableOperationAsync.

trans-unit.source: The next time that PushAsync() is called, these changes will be sent to the server.
trans-unit.target: The next time that PushAsync() is called, these changes will be sent to the server.

trans-unit.source: When a push is canceled, PushAsync will throw a MobileServicePushFailedException, and the exception property PushResult.Status will have the value MobileServicePushStatus.CancelledByOperation.
trans-unit.target: When a push is canceled, PushAsync will throw a MobileServicePushFailedException, and the exception property PushResult.Status will have the value MobileServicePushStatus.CancelledByOperation.
